text: it's a beautiful little neighborhood
with these brownstones beautiful trees
on the street people outside a lot of
old timers a lot of families lots of
mom-and-pop stores you come out of the
subway station and it's just it's a
really special place
this neighborhood is only like maybe
four blocks wide and when you're on a
corner it's like two three blocks in
each direction and that's it
Carroll Gardens was all part of Red Hook
back in the sixties I decided we're
gonna call it Carroll Gardens Carroll
because of Carroll Park and Gardens
because we had this unique front gardens
Carroll Gardens was laid out and built
according to a master plan which asked
for gardens in the front and in the back
and it creates a pretty good niek
streetscape all the restaurants
typically have gardens there's a lot of
outdoor seating it has very much a
small-town feel within the larger city
growing up it would take 20-30 minutes
to walk two blocks you had to say hello
to everybody and they would just strike
up a conversation the shop owners tend
to go out of their way to actually learn
who you are and get to know you the F
and the G service Carroll Gardens
primarily I think a lot of people have a
love-hate relationship with the F train
but if you're going into Midtown or
downtown it's it's it's a great mode of
transportation it's also close to
Manhattan you can literally walk from
Carroll Gardens over the Brooklyn Bridge
what really shocked me was the amount of
cabs that you could get here the only
problem is parking you can't park you
got this neighborhood used to be
Scandinavian mostly because of the
Seaport as they moved out of the
neighborhood who you had Italians who
moved in first into Red Hook and then
into what we now call Carroll Gardens
when my father immigrated here back in
1909 or thereabouts this was an Italian
ghetto desperately poor neighborhood
Al Capone got married here on Court
Street most of the people from this area
came from a town in Sicily called
Palazzo
I was born and raised here thinking the
whole world was italian-american because
everybody here was italian-american you
could buy a brownstone back in the 70s
for like forty thousand 50 thousand
dollars
people started coming in and it started
changing people that did live here they
can't afford it when I first moved into
this neighborhood thirty years ago if
you wanted meat you went to the butcher
if you wanted vegetables you went to
Florence on quartz feed we've lost a lot
of you know those little mom-and-pop
shops I think for the first time it's
going to change for the worse one of the
reasons for this neighborhood becoming
so desirable is the schools there's no
room in the schools anymore so they're
putting these trailer units in the
school yards and creating more
classrooms try to get your child into PS
58 it's very difficult even if your zone
for the school 4,000 units are coming to
market over the next two years and like
I won't where all these kids will go to
school today the markets just fierce
you know people who want to buy a
brownstone they're coming in ready
rental prices are going up - I don't
think there's anything that could make

you know even now I walk the streets and
it's like Oh so-and-so used to live
there and so-and-so used to live there
and people ask me like tell me what it
was like back in the day here you know
there was this tiny little area that
nobody really knew about and then word
